Sex Capital Markets: Leveraging AI and crypto to address issues faced by adult content creators

Moxie founder Neonwight outlined the platform’s strategy for combining artificial intelligence (AI) with crypto to create “Sex Capital Markets.” He said the controversial concept was fundamentally about…

external.description: Moxie founder Neonwight outlined the platform’s strategy for combining artificial intelligence (AI) with crypto to create “Sex Capital Markets.” He said the controversial concept was fundamentally about financial inclusivity and unlocking productivity for marginalized creators.  He stated in an interview with CryptoSlate: “Adult creators are one of the most marginalized professions in society. Banks refuse to serve them, and Visa and Mastercard charge north of 10% to 15% processing fees because they view adult content as legal and reputational risk.” Neonwight detailed personal experiences with banking discrimination, citing instances where his bank blocked OnlyFans payments after two transactions.
external.title: Sex Capital Markets: Leveraging AI and crypto to address issues faced by adult content creators

But I also think there's something telling about the exchange. Earlier this year, I took note of the incident in which Meta gamed benchmarks to try to make Llama 4 look better than it actually was. In its aftermath, though, Mark Zuckerberg blew up his AI organization and reportedly has spent hundreds of millions of dollars recruiting top researchers in hopes of catching up to the competition.

In Musk's feeble antitrust claim this week, I see a similar adverse indicator: a case in which a giant of technology comes to understand that it has fallen behind, and immediately kicks up a cloud of dust to distract from it.

record.text: Wrote about the backlash to GPT-5 and the dawning awareness inside labs of just how strongly some people feel about individual models and workflows https://www.platformer.news/gpt-5-backlash-openai-lessons/

images.alt:
Third, and most obviously: it's hard to make changes to products that are used by hundreds of millions of people. For years, I wondered why the Google Docs team seemed to be shipping new features at a rate of roughly one per year. Eventually, I spoke with people on the team. And the basic answer was simply: users hate change. Better to stick with a design that mostly worked than to incur the wrath of millions of people because you moved their favorite feature, or took it away.

At 700 million weekly users, ChatGPT is now well on its way to Google Docs scale. And that's likely going to incentivize slower, more considered changes to its flagship product.

The Dead Need Right To Delete Their Data So They Can't Be AI-ified, Lawyer Says

Victoria Haneman proposes granting estates a temporary right to delete a deceased person's data to prevent AI-driven digital resurrection without consent. She highlights the increasing amount of personal dat…

#ai #news

external.description: Victoria Haneman proposes granting estates a temporary right to delete a deceased person's data to prevent AI-driven digital resurrection without consent. She highlights the increasing amount of personal data stored online and its potential misuse, comparing data to uranium. Current US law offers limited data protection for the deceased, leaving digital assets vulnerable. The Revised Uniform Fiduciary Access to Digital Assets Act (RUFADAA) and platform policies like Facebook's memorialization offer inadequate solutions. While some states have right of publicity laws, their monetization is complex. Libel and defamation laws for the deceased exist in some states, but face constitutional challenges. California's Delete Act offers data deletion for the living but its extension to the dead is uncertain. Haneman draws parallels to laws protecting human remains, arguing that digital data deserves similar consideration. She advocates for a limited 12-month deletion window, balancing societal interests with the deceased's rights. This right would allow the destruction of digital data comparable to physical letters and photographs.
external.title: The Dead Need Right To Delete Their Data So They Can't Be AI-ified, Lawyer Says

external.description: Victoria Haneman proposes granting estates a temporary right to delete a deceased person's data to prevent AI-driven digital resurrection without consent. She highlights the increasing amount of personal data stored online and its potential misuse, comparing data to uranium. Current US law offers limited data protection for the deceased, leaving digital assets vulnerable. The Revised Uniform Fiduciary Access to Digital Assets Act (RUFADAA) and platform policies like Facebook's memorialization offer inadequate solutions. While some states have right of publicity laws, their monetization is complex. Libel and defamation laws for the deceased exist in some states, but face constitutional challenges. California's Delete Act offers data deletion for the living but its extension to the dead is uncertain. Haneman draws parallels to laws protecting human remains, arguing that digital data deserves similar consideration. She advocates for a limited 12-month deletion window, balancing societal interests with the deceased's rights. This right would allow the destruction of digital data comparable to physical letters and photographs.
external.title: The Dead Need Right To Delete Their Data So They Can't Be AI-ified, Lawyer Says

Space Force officials take secrecy to new heights ahead of key rocket launch

The Vulcan rocket checks off several important boxes for the Space Force. First, it relies entirely on US-made rocket engines. The Atlas V rocket it is replacing uses Russian-built main engines, and given the chilled…

external.description: The Vulcan rocket checks off several important boxes for the Space Force. First, it relies entirely on US-made rocket engines. The Atlas V rocket it is replacing uses Russian-built main engines, and given the chilled relations between the two powers, US officials have long desired to stop using Russian engines to power the Pentagon's satellites into orbit. Second, ULA says the Vulcan rocket will eventually provide a heavy-lift launch capability at a lower cost than the company's now-retired Delta IV Heavy rocket. Third, Vulcan provides the Space Force with an alternative to SpaceX's Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy, which have been the only rockets in their class available to the military since the last national security mission was launched on an Atlas V rocket one year ago.
external.title: Space Force officials take secrecy to new heights ahead of key rocket launch

record.text:
こんなの少し考えればおかしいとわかるのにだ。

ここで簡略化されて話された説明はどこまでも、どこかごまかしが含まれてる説明で、その誤魔化しを感じさせない欺瞞に満ちた文章にならざるを得ない。

だが、実際、説明できることが理解度合いだ、と多くの人に支持され、その風潮はまだまだ残ってる。

自分にとって納得できる情報を好み、それを与えてくれる人を評価している。そこには、自分の頭で考える、自分の足で探求するといったものはない。

多くの人はわかりやすい説明に弱い。その内容が如何なるものでも、科学的っぽくて、論理的っぽくて、イメージしやすければなんだっていいとしてる。

完全に同意。

正直、今の大半の人類の思考レベルではどうしてもChatGPTの答えを鵜呑みにするから、今はこういう対策が大事だと思う。

ここらへんは「科学的、論理的、に見える文章に権力を与えるな」というポスト構成主義的に思考が一般化しない限り難しいと思う。

これは科学が絶対的な正解を提供してくれるというような幻想が流行りすぎたことによる問題でもあると僕は思ってる。

科学的な文章、つまりなんとなく納得させられる文章に多くの人は弱い。

最近は少し薄れてきてるが、少し前まで世間は「理解してるということは誰にでもわかりやすく説明できることだ」とよく言っていた。

record.text:
うーん。まぁまぁ頭の片隅には置いておきましょうって感じ。

個人的にDeppSeekの記述については疑問に思う。

DeppSeekの大きな貢献はLLMのオープンソースであり、現在はローカルで動かすならDeppSeekという風潮がある。

gptもオープンで出されたけど、大きすぎるし回してみても実用的な速度じゃなかったりで、あんまりローカル方面ではシェアを獲得できてない。

だから、チャットUIをWebServiceで提供してるところとDeppSeekを比較するのはかなりナンセンスに思う。戦ってる土俵が違うと僕は思う。

external.description: 生成AIの急速な普及により、Webでの調べものが根本的に変化している。プログラミングを支援するAIコーディングアシスタントへのアクセスは75％も急増する一方、プログラマー向けQ&Aサイトのトラフィックは14％減少した。さらに深刻な影響を受けているのがフリーランス市場だ。多くの小規模プロジェクトが生成AIで処理可能になったためとみられる。教育分野でも、とあるサイトが62％の急落を記録するなど、AIが一部ビジネスモデルを根底から揺るがしている。

It's not just in-context learning, as gained information can be persistently stored by additional mechanisms, as e.g. ChatGPT, Claude and Letta memory features demonstrate, and later transferred to weights through slower processes (not that different from memory consolidation in brains).

And:

value.text: I think it's an open question whether it makes sense to try to change the weights themselves in a continual fashion. People tend to forget that the way it happens in our brains wouldn't be acceptable from an AI. For us, catastrophic forgetting is a normal feature. We forget what isn't refreshed.

record.text:
It's fundamentally a neural net like my brain. The guardrails are similar kinds of limits as laws are for me.

As for free will, do you actually believe there's such thing?

All talk I have ever seen about the significance of embodiment for consciousness is about as handwavy as things get.

It's a god of the gaps type of thing. Pointing towards the general direction of a proposed remaining gap.

value.text:
That's no doubt common. But if people actually believed so on a more rational level, it shouldn't be so hard to make arguments for it.

All the embodied consciousness talk is so handwavy that I have never understood what they are really even trying to propose. There's no theory.

value.text:
instead of AGI we got.. gpt-4o withdrawal

unexpectedly (or maybe expectedly), users formed a psychological bond with 4o and ripping it away seems to have cut them deep

where to go from here?

images.alt:
Sam Altman
@sama
If you have been following the GPT-5 rollout, one thing you might be noticing is how much of an attachment some people have to specific Al models. It feels different and stronger than the kinds of attachment people have had to previous kinds of technology (and so suddenly deprecating old models that users depended on in their workflows was a mistake).
This is something we've been closely tracking for the past year or so but still hasn't gotten much mainstream attention (other than when we released an update to GPT-4o that was too sycophantic).
(This is just my current thinking, and not yet an official OpenAl position.)
People have used technology including Al in self-destructive ways; if a user is in a mentally fragile state and prone to delusion, we do not want the Al to reinforce that. Most users can keep a clear line between reality and fiction or role-play, but a small percentage cannot. We value user freedom as a core principle, but we also feel responsible

as a core principle, but we also feel responsible in how we introduce new technology with new risks.
Encouraging delusion in a user that is having trouble telling the difference between reality and fiction is an extreme case and it's pretty clear what to do, but the concerns that worry me most are more subtle. There are going to be a lot of edge cases, and generally we plan to follow the principle of "treat adult users like adults" , which
in some cases will include pushing back on users to ensure they are getting what they really want.
A lot of people effectively use ChatGPT as a sort of therapist or life coach, even if they wouldn't describe it that way. This can be really good! A lot of people are getting value from it already today.
If people are getting good advice, leveling up toward their own goals, and their life satisfaction is increasing over years, we will be proud of making something genuinely helpful, even if they use and rely on ChatGPT a lot. If, on the other hand, users have a relationship with ChatGPT where they think they feel better after talking but they're unknowingly nudged away from their

making something genuinely helpful, even it they use and rely on ChatGPT a lot. If, on the other hand, users have a relationship with ChatGPT where they think they feel better after talking but they're unknowingly nudged away from their longer term well-being (however they define it), that's bad. It's also bad, for example, if a user wants to use ChatGPT less and feels like they cannot.
I can imagine a future where a lot of people really trust ChatGPT's advice for their most important decisions. Although that could be great, it makes me uneasy. But I expect that it is coming to some degree, and soon billions of people may be talking to an Al in this way. So we (we as in society, but also we as in OpenAl) have to figure out how to make it a big net positive.
There are several reasons I think we have a good shot at getting this right. We have much better tech to help us measure how we are doing than previous generations of technology had. For example, our product can talk to users to get a sense for how they are doing with their short-and long-term goals, we can explain sophisticated and nuanced issues to our models, and much more.
